Graphical abstract We demonstrated catalytic removal of naphthenic acids in highly acidic crude oil over catalyst prepared by impregnating CoO-MoO3 on mesoporous γ-Al2O3, and its sulfidate-form treated via post-synthetic sulfidation treatment to increase activity at lower temperature. We used almost real highly acidic crude prepared mixing heavy Castilla crude oil and naphthenic acids; total-acid-number (TAN) of this feedstock was 2.192 mgKOH/g. Our target TAN of product was 0.5 mgKOH/g (requirement of conventional refinery industry). For optimizing reaction conditions, temperature, hydrogen-pressure, hydrogen-to-oil (H2/oil) ratio and liquid-hourly-space-velocity (LHSV) of feed were screened. The oxide-form catalyst reduced TAN to lower than 0.5 mgKOH/g for 82 h, under optimized condition (T = 350 °C, PH2 = 0.5 MPa, H2/oil = 25 Nm3/m3, and LHSVfeed = 10 h−1). After sulfidation, this catalyst achieved target TAN at lower temperature (250℃) for 72 h (PH2 = 4.0 MPa, H2/oil = 50 Nm3/m3, and LHSVfeed = 3 h−1). Mechanism study shows that the removal of naphthenic acids occurred mainly through decarboxylation, decarbonylation and hydrodeoxygenation. Keywords Highly acidic crude oil Naphthenic acids Real crude oil Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 Sulfidation Decarboxylation 1 Introduction In recent years, the increase of oil demand and consumption by population growth and technology developments has caused an unavoidable decline of conventional petroleum oil reserves, and consequently is driving many countries to explore and to utilize unconventional crudes [1]. Most unconventional crudes are known to be highly acidic due to the presence of naphthenic acids. Crude oil with a total acid number (TAN, the weight of KOH required to neutralize a gram of acidic crude oil, determined according to ASTM D664 protocol) higher than 0.5 mgKOH/g is normally referred to as acidic crude oil, and the crude oil with TAN higher than 1.0 mgKOH/g is referred to highly acidic crude oil [2,3]. The production of acidic crude oil has been increasing by 0.3 %/y in recent years in the world, and it is considered to be the most practical alternative to conventional crude oils due to relatively lower price and greater availability and about 9 million barrels per day have been consumed in recent years [4–6]. However, the acidic crude oil causes corrosion problems in conventional refinery facilities of heavy crude oil, which should be neutralized before the refinery process. Naphthenic acids (NAs) are naturally-existing compounds of aliphatic, monocyclic, and polycyclic carboxylic acids, which is the reason for increases of TAN in crude oil. Direct refinery of high TAN crudes in conventional facilities causes serious corrosion problems in up- and down-stream processing units, as well as product quality issues [7,8]. Therefore, it is highly desirable to develop a cost-effective technique for the removal of naphthenic acids from high TAN crudes. There are two main industrially applicable processes for TAN reduction of acidic crudes. One is the use of NaOH (caustic washing) with electric treatment, which converts the NAs into neutralized salts, but the generation of a large amount of wastewater is a serious limitation. The other method is dilution of the acidic crude oil by low TAN crude oil to reduce the corrosive and toxic impact of naphthenic acids. However, the content of high TAN in the blended crude oil is typically very low (around 2–3%), and these NAs are not fundamentally removed from the crude oil mixture. Some low-boiling-point NAs therefore may be present in the light components emitted from the distillation unit, and high-boiling-point NAs may accumulate in the heavy components or residues. As well as the above practical methods, various methods of reducing TAN at the academic research level have been proposed: ionic-liquid treatment [9,10], catalytic esterification [11–17], catalytic decarboxylation [18–21], ammonia treatment [22], microwave-radiative treatment [23], adsorption [24], and solvent extraction [25]. These processes still have disadvantages that should be resolved prior to practical application. Although the TAN can be reduced using ionic liquid or ammonia and subsequent solvent extraction, these methods are uneconomical due to the high cost of chemicals, heterogeneous catalysts, and hydrogen. The catalytic decarboxylation method uses alkali, alkaline earth metal oxides [18,25], and hydrotalcite [26] as a reactant, but the operation at high temperature (>300℃) is necessary for effective removal of the acidic group [27–29]. Moreover, catalytic deactivation occurs by coking and generating metal naphthenate. Solvent extraction requires a large amount of solvent and has a major problem with solvent recovery and recycle. As shown above, it is very important to develop a simple, cost-effective, and eco-friendly process for reducing the TAN of acidic crude oil, to an industrial level. In this study, we develop an effective method for TAN reduction of highly acidic crude, based on catalytic removal of NAs in the crude, using CoO-MoO3 or NiO-MoO3 supported on γ-Al2O3 as a catalyst. We performed systematic catalytic studies of this reaction with variation of the reaction conditions such as reaction temperature, pressure, H2/oil ratio, and feed rate, and we confirmed that the TAN reaction was possible under moderate reaction conditions, where the present catalyst was used. Especially, this catalyst was tested after sulfidation treatment, in order to enhance the catalytic performance at relatively low temperature (523 K) which is more favorable from the view point of industry. A mechanistic study on this reaction was also performed to verify the role of the present catalyst on the removal of NAs, as considering previous mechanism studies for acid removal of naphthenic acid [30–34]. Moreover, the long-term test of catalytic stability was performed to assess the possibility of this method for TAN removal in the real field. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Material and reagents The naphthenic acids with TAN value of 200 mg KOH/g was purchased from Sigma Aldrich. The heavy crude oil (Castilla Crude Oil) was received from Venezuela through Hyundai Oilbank, and the basic chemical properties of this heavy crude are given in Table 1 . Isopropanol and toluene (HPLC grade) were purchased from SAMCHUN Chemical. Precursors used for the synthesis of the TAN-reduction catalyst, ammonium heptamolybdate [(NH4)6Mo7O24.4H2O, 99.98 % purity], cobalt nitrate [Co(NO3)2.6H2O, 99.98 % purity), and phosphoric acids (H3PO4, 99.98 % purity) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Supporting material, γ-Al2O3, was purchased from Sasol, Germany. Dimethyl disulfide (DMDS) and kerosene, which were used to sulfidate the catalyst were purchased from Samchun Chemical. 2.2 Preparation of highly acidic crude oil feedstock We prepared the high TAN crude oil feed by adding commercial naphthenic acid into Venezuela heavy crude oil to adjust the TAN value to 2.192 (±0.01) mg KOH/g of oil. Considering the classification of acidic crude oil, the present feed is highly acidic crude oil [3]. The feed mixture was mechanically stirred overnight at room temperature to ensure a uniform composition in the feed. 2.3 Catalysts preparation Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was prepared via incipient wetness impregnation of cobalt and molybdenum precursor into mesoporous γ-Al2O3 supporting material with the addition of tiny amount of phosphoric acid (for enhancing the dispersion of the cobalt and molybdenum metal species), and subsequent calcination [35–38]. In the impregnation step, 6.32 g of cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2.6H2O, cobalt precursor) and 4.88 g of ammonium heptamolybdate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24.4H2O, molybdenum precursor) were clearly dissolved in 20 g of distilled water. The cobalt metal species and molybdenum metal species were present in the solution with a 1:1 atomic ratio. This precursor solution was added dropwise to 20 g of γ-Al2O3 (dried at 373 K for 8 h before the impregnation step), and the γ-Al2O3 powder adsorbing the precursor solution was agitated thoroughly to enhance the dispersion of the precursor solution in the pore channel of the γ-Al2O3. The powder was dried at 353 K for 6 h in a drying oven, in order to remove the water solvent, and it was calcined at 723 K under a dried air flow (flow rate = 300 cm3/min). After calcination, the cobalt and molybdenum precursor may be converted to oxide forms, CoO and MoO3, respectively, inside the pore channel of γ-Al2O3. 2.4 Catalysts characterization N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of the catalysts were obtained using a volumetric sorption analyzer (Micromeritics ASAP 2020). Before analysis, samples were degassed at 300℃ for 5 h under a vacuum condition, in order to remove water vapor or VOC adsorbed from the atmosphere. Surface area was calculated from the N2 adsorption curve using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, and the total pore volume was calculated from the volume of N2 adsorbed at relative pressure P/P0 0.97. The pore size distribution was assessed from the desorption branch using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. The sulfur content of the Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in sulfide form was measured using an Antek 5000 system, according to ASTM D5453−93. 0.5 g of the catalyst was placed in a sample boat, and this boat was placed in a high temperature (∼1000℃) combustion tube where the sulfur is oxidized to sulfur dioxide (SO2) in an oxygen rich atmosphere. Water that was generated during the combustion was removed, and the out-gas was exposed to ultraviolet light. The SO2 was converted to excited sulfur dioxide (SO2*) after absorbing the energy from the UV light. The fluorescence emitted from the SO2* when it returns to a stable state SO2 was then detected by a photomultiplier tube. Finally, the resulting signal became an index for measuring the sulfur contained in the catalyst. 2.5 Catalytic reaction The catalytic reaction to remove naphthenic acids in highly acidic crude oil was carried out in a fixed-bed up-flow reactor (1.0 cm in inner diameter and 45 cm in length). The reaction temperature was monitored with a thermocouple inserted into the middle of the catalyst bed. 12 mL of the catalyst was loaded in the stainless-steel reactor to obtain sufficient catalyst-bed length. A schematic diagram of the fixed bed up-flow micro-reactor is shown in Fig. 1 . The feed system effectively maintains constant homogeneity of the TAN by continuous mechanical stirring. Hydrogen gas and the highly acidic crude oil (liquid) were well mixed through a line-mixer, and the pressure of the hydrogen was controlled using a back-pressure-regulator. The temperature of the reaction was controlled by a heater. The liquid product was quenched by chilled-water (10℃) condenser, separated from product mixture, and gathered in liquid product tank. Prior to the catalytic reaction, the catalyst was heated to 250℃ (ramping rate = 10℃ min−1) under a N2 flow (flow rate = 100 cm3 min−1), and the temperature was maintained for 2 h. When the catalyst in sulfide-form was used in the reaction, the catalyst in oxide form was chemically treated in another reactor column using 2.5 wt% DMDS in kerosene as a sulfiding agent. The 2.5 wt% DMDS in kerosene was added into the catalyst with flow rate of 2 cm3 min-1, and the catalyst was heated to 250℃ for 5 h under H2 pressure of 0.5 MPa. After the sulfidation treatment, the sulfidated catalyst was thoroughly washed by kerosene at 250℃. After the pre-treatment of the catalyst, the temperature of the catalyst was changed to the reaction temperature (250∼350℃), the N2 flow was changed to H2 flow, and highly acidic crude oil feedstock was injected by a HPLC pump into the catalytic reaction system. For example, when H2/oil and LHSVfeed were 25 Nm3 m−3 and 10 h−1, respectively (reaction conditions for long-term catalytic stability test of Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in oxide form), the flow rates of the H2 gas and the crude oil feedstock were 50 sccm and 2 cm3 min−1, respectively. H2 gas and the feedstock were uniformly mixed through a line mixer located immediately the entrance of the reactor, and the reactant mixture (H2 and the highly acidic crude oil) was injected to the reactor containing the catalyst. The pressure inside the reactor was increased to a specific reaction pressure (0.1∼5.0 MPa) by the back-pressure-regulator. Within 10 min of starting the injection of the reactant mixture, the desired H2/oil, LHSVfeed, and reaction pressure were sufficiently stabilized. The liquid product was then gathered for 10 min, and the TAN of the liquid product and the consequent initial catalytic activity of the catalyst were measured. Meanwhile, the gas-phase product (off gas) was analyzed using a GC attached to the outlet of the product condenser. 2.6 Product characterization The product crude oil was collected at different reaction times of catalytic TAN reduction, and it was characterized using several analysis methods. The TAN of the product was evaluated using the ASTM D664 potentiometric titration method. TAN is the mass of potassium hydroxide (KOH) in milligrams that is required to neutralize one gram of chemical substance. The simulated distillation curve was determined via an Agilent 6890N-GC according to the ASTM D-7213 procedure. The density and API gravity of the crude oil feed and product were measured using an Anton-Paar density/concentration meter DMA 4500, according to ASTM D-1052. The concentration of sulfur and nitrogen was measured using an Antek 5000 analyzer, according to ASTM D5453-93 and ASTM D4629 procedures, respectively. Total carbon concentration was measured using a CHN LECO 800 analyzer. Once total carbon, hydrogen, sulfur, and nitrogen wt% are determined, the oxygen concentration is indirectly determined assuming that the crude oil is composed of carbon, hydrogen, sulfur, nitrogen, and oxygen. The reactant gases are analyzed offline using a Agilent-Packard 5890 Series II-GC that is equipped with two different detectors, a Thermal Conductivity Detector (TCD) and a Flame Ionization Detector (FID). The TCD is used for the analysis of H2, CO, CO2, O2, N2 and H2S, while the FID is used for CH4 and C2–C6, hydrocarbons. 2.7 Determination of TAN and naphthenic acid removal In the present study, the total acid number (TAN) determination of feed and product crude oils was routinely carried out by a standard method in the oil industry using ASTM D664, and the formula of the deacidification rate was as follows: The efficiency of the catalyst used in the removal of naphthenic acids in highly acidic crude oil was calculated as the percentage of acid removal (%AR). A c i d R e m o v a l % = T A N F e e d C r u d e O i l - T A N P r o d u c t C r u d e O i l T A N F e e d C r u d e O i l 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Feedstock analysis Prior to the synthesis of catalysts and the evaluation of the catalytic TAN reduction, we characterized the physico-chemical properties (such as carbon number distribution and components) of commercial naphthenic acid and heavy crude oil that were used to make highly acidic crude feedstock (as described in chapter 2.1). These properties were estimated from the boiling point and the chemical mapping, using SIMDIS based on the extended ASTM D 2887 method. Fig. 2 shows the results of the SIMDIS analysis for the naphthenic acid. As shown in Fig. 2, the naphthenic acid reagent is composed of alkane species and mono-aromatic species as the main components, and a tiny amount of multi-aromatic (above two rings) species. These three different groups were shown in two-dimensional GC profile as three different layers. In the case of the major components, several dots are separately shown in the range of 2000 s ∼ 6000 s, indicating that the boiling point of the alkane species ranges from 213℃ (IBP) to 449℃ (FBP), mainly from 250℃ to 350℃. The alkane species with the boiling point in the aforementioned range covers n-dodecane (n-C12) ∼ n-dotriacontane (n-C32), and this means that the naphthenic acid is composed of jet kerosene, fuel oil, diesel fuel, and light vacuum gas oil (LVGO). In the case of aromatic compounds, the distribution of the boiling point and consequent carbon number appears to be quite uniform, although it is difficult to characterize the variation of molecular structures of the aromatics in this analysis. The heavy crude oil used in this work was imported from Venezuela via Hyundai Oilbank, and it shows typical properties of heavy crude oil. As described in Table 1, this oil shows 0.94 kg m–3 density and 18.2 API gravity (at 60 °F). When the naphthenic acid was added to this heavy crude oil to adjust TAN to 2.192 (±0.01) mgKOH/g, the feed oil becomes close to normal unconventional and highly acidic crude oil. Since we used real heavy crude oil, the feedstock that was used in this work appears to be very similar to naturally-existing highly acidic crude oil. We did not use a simple model feedstock, and thus the present catalytic study using this feedstock is quite meaningful and highly reliable to confirm the possibility of the catalytic reaction and the present catalyst in application in the real refinery industry. 3.2 Characterization of catalyst The present catalyst used for TAN reduction of the highly acidic crude oil was prepared via the impregnation of cobalt precursor (cobalt nitrate) and molybdenum precursor (ammonium heptamolybdate) into common γ-Al2O3 and subsequent calcination. Phosphoric acid was also impregnated with other precursors, in order to enhance the dispersion of the metal catalysts [35–38]. After the calcination treatment, the cobalt and molybdenum precursors converted to oxide forms, CoO and MoO3, respectively. The synthesized catalyst is referred to as Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 for convenience. Fig. 3 a shows the XRD patterns of the Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3, exhibiting three broad peaks indicating γ-Al2O3 phase. However, strong peaks for Co-Mo oxide alloy (CoMoO4, normally observed at 26° of two theta), CoO (observed at 35°), and MoO3 (observed at 27°) were not observed, and this indicates that the Co-Mo catalyst was well dispersed on the γ-Al2O3 supporting material with quite small particle size. The cobalt and molybdenum oxides were likely generated in alloy form (not in separated two phases), which could be confirmed by hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurement. Fig. 4 a shows the results of H2-TPR measurement for the Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, exhibiting a sharp strong peak centered at 425℃, and a broad weak peak at around 750℃. The broad peak at 750℃ is owing to molybdenum species strongly interacting with the alumina support and therefore corresponds to CoMoO4 species [39]. The sharp peak at 425℃ corresponds to the reduction of Co-Mo catalyst in oxide form. If the cobalt and molybdenum oxides were separately generated, there were two separated reduction peak. The single sharp reduction peak can support the generation of single phase Co-Mo catalyst in oxide form. Fig. 3b shows the nitrogen sorption isotherm of Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3, which was measured at 77 K. The BET surface area, total pore volume, and pore diameter are derived from this isotherm, and these values are described in Table 2 . The synthesized Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 exhibits a type IV N2 sorption isotherm with an H3 hysteresis loop, which is typical characteristics of a mesoporous material, and it shows 201.95 m2/g BET surface area, 0.486 cm3/g total pore volume, and 7.5 nm median mesopore diameter. These values are quite similar to those of the bare γ-Al2O3 supporting material (Sasol product). These results indicate that the Co-Mo catalyst was well impregnated into the supporting material without pore blocking. The Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst is almost a mesoporous material showing uniform pore diameter. The acid property of the Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was characterized by ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD). As shown in the NH3-TPD profile in Fig. 4b, the Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst shows a similar plot trend to bare γ-Al2O3. The desorption peak centered at 200℃ corresponds to the weak acid that is present in γ-Al2O3, and the formation of Co-Mo species in the catalyst does not affect the generation of acidity. Notably, in the acid removal reaction from the crude oil, the hydrogenation ability of the Co-Mo species is more important than the acidity of the catalyst. 3.3 Catalytic properties of catalyst in oxide form In this work, our goal is to reduce the TAN of the highly acidic crude oil from 2.192 mg KOH/g to 0.5 mgKOH/g, which is at least value to meet the requirement of non-acidic crude handled in the refinery industry, via a catalytic reaction using the present Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. The decrease of TAN means that naphthenic acid in highly acidic crude oil was chemically removed, and the product crude oil becomes less acidic. There are four important reaction parameters affecting the performance and efficiency of the catalytic reaction: 1) reaction temperature (T) affecting the activity of the catalyst, CAPEX of the reactor (dependent to reactor material); and OPEX of the process operation, 2) pressure of hydrogen (PH2) affecting the contact of hydrogen to the catalyst and the crude oil, the consequent conversion rate, and also CAPEX of the reactor set-up (reactor design, and compressor type); 3) H2/oil ratio affecting the conversion rate of feed, product selectivity, and OPEX in hydrogen consumption; and 4) space velocity of the feedstock (LHSVfeed) affecting the productivity of the catalyst, and the size of reactor in process. In order to confirm the possibility of the present Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 as a catalyst for TAN reduction of the highly acidic crude oil and to optimize the reaction conditions, we tested the catalytic performance of the catalyst with varying reaction conditions including the aforementioned four parameters. First, we confirmed the catalytic activity at three different reaction temperatures (300℃, 325℃, and 350℃) under 0.5 MPa of PH2, 25 Nm3/m3 of H2/oil, and 2.5 h−1 of LHSVfeed. The Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (6.8 wt% CoO, 13.1 wt% MoO3, Co/Mo = 1 in atomic ratio) was tested in oxide form (without sulfidation treatment). For 10 min after the feed mixture of highly acidic crude oil and hydrogen was injected under a certain reaction conditions, we expected that the H2/oil ratio in feed stream and the reaction conditions could be sufficiently stabilized. Subsequently, liquid product was gathered for 10 min, and TAN of the liquid product and consequent initial catalytic activity of the catalyst were measured. As shown in Fig. 5 , the TAN of the product decreases with increasing the reaction temperature. It was lower than 0.5 mgKOH/g when the reaction was performed at 325℃, and 350℃, but we could not achieve target TAN number at 300℃. In this test, we confirmed that the present Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in oxide form shows satisfactory catalytic activity in TAN reduction at 350℃. Notably, 350℃ reaction temperature and 0.5 MPa PH2 are not harsh conditions, considering the operation conditions of a normal refinery process. Under the same conditions (350℃ reaction temperature, 0.5 MPa PH2, 25 Nm3/m3 H2/oil, and 2.5 h−1 LHSVfeed) of the catalytic evaluation, we also tested other catalysts that had different Co-Mo loading amounts (3.4 wt% CoO, 6.5 wt% MoO3; 10.2 wt% CoO, 19.7 wt% MoO3) or different Co/Mo atomic ratios (Co/Mo = 0.5, 0.75, and 1.5), or that were synthesized by impregnating nickel species instead of cobalt. When the loading amount of CoO and MoO3 decreased to 3.4 wt% and 6.5 wt%, respectively, the catalytic activity for TAN reduction reduced 41 %, as compared to the Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (6.8 wt% CoO, 13.1 wt% MoO3). When the loading amount of CoO and MoO3 was increased to 10.2 wt% and 19.7 wt%, respectively, the catalytic activity was reduced 10 %. This indicates that some excessively loaded Co-Mo species might partially block the mesopores of the alumina support material. Among the various loading amounts of Co-Mo species, 6.8 wt% CoO and 13.1 wt% MoO3 were the optimized amounts to show the highest catalytic TAN reduction. In the case of another variable factor, Co/Mo atomic ratio, Co/Mo = 1 was the optimized ratio in terms of showing the highest catalytic TAN reduction. In addition, the Ni-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (Ni/Mo = 1) exhibited almost the same catalytic properties as the Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (6.8 wt% CoO, 13.1 wt% MoO3, Co/Mo = 1). Therefore, we decided to focus on the Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (6.8 wt% CoO, 13.1 wt% MoO3, Co/Mo = 1) in further catalytic evaluations of this present work. As mentioned above, in order to optimize the reaction conditions, we tested the catalytic properties of the present catalyst while also varying PH2, H2/oil ratio, and LHSVfeed. Standard conditions were 350℃ reaction temperature, 0.5 MPa PH2, 25 Nm3/m3 H2/oil ratio, and 2.5 LHSVfeed. The catalytic results measured with variation of the reaction parameters are shown in Fig. 6 . The TAN of the final product decreased with increasing PH2 (Fig. 6a), increasing H2/oil ratio (Fig. 6b), and decreasing LHSVfeed (Fig. 6c). In the case of PH2, where the other parameters are unchanged, PH2 should be higher than 0.1 MPa to reduce the TAN of product crude oil below 0.5 mgKOH/g (Fig. 6a). The H2/oil ratio should be higher than 5 Nm3/m3 to achieve the target TAN where the other parameters are the same as the standard condition (Fig. 6b). In the case of LHSVfeed, the TAN of the product was not significantly changed in the range of 1.5 ∼ 10 h−1. When the LHSVfeed was 10 h−1, the TAN of the feedstock was sufficiently reduced to below the target level (to 0.35 mgKOH/g). From these systematic catalytic studies on the present Co-Mo//γ-Al2O3 catalyst in oxide form, we could confirm the effect of various reaction parameters on TAN reduction, and find the optimized conditions. Focusing on the reduction of the reaction temperature (reducing operation cost and saving energy), 325℃ reaction temperature, 0.5 MPa PH2, 25 Nm3/m3 H2/oil ratio, and 2.5 LHSVfeed are the optimized conditions to meet the desired level of TAN in product. Focusing on maximizing productivity by increasing LHSVfeed, 350℃ reaction temperature, 0.5 MPa PH2, 25 Nm3/m3 H2/oil ratio, and 10 h−1 LHSVfeed are the optimized conditions. Under this condition with high LHSVfeed (10 h−1), a long-term stability test was also performed for the present catalyst. As shown in Fig. 7 , the Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in oxide form can reduce the TAN of the highly acidic crude oil to below 0.5 mgKOH/g for 82 h of time on stream. A significant increase of the TAN of the final product was not shown until 82 h of reaction, and thus it is likely that the catalytic activity will be well maintained for further reaction time. However, according to comments of a co-author (Kim, C.-H.) of this work who is the head of the R&D research institute of Hyundai Oilbank (one of the top three refinery companies in South Korea), the above reaction conditions are still not desirable (specifically they are energy-consuming and costly) in the real refinery industry, in order to reduce the entire cost of the catalytic process. The pressure of hydrogen in the reactor is allowable up to 5.0 MPa, when the conventional facilities including the reactor of the refinery process are used. The H2/oil ratio is not a critical factor because hydrogen is cheap and a surplus species in refinery and petrochemical industries. On the other hand, it would be better to decrease the reaction temperature as much as possible. If the reaction temperature was decreased to below 250℃, an additional heater (or heat exchanger) would not be necessary. The unit of TAN reduction using the Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst can be inserted in the middle of a certain process where the temperature of crude oil is around 250℃ to avoid additional heating. Moreover, it is possible to use waste heat. In the case of LHSVfeed, this factor is directly dependent on the productivity of the process, and thus it is desirable to increase it as much as possible. Following such requirements and comments from real industrial fields, the Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in oxide form was tested at below 300℃, where the pressure of hydrogen, H2/Oil ratio, and LHSVfeed were 5.0 MPa, 25 Nm3/m3, and 5 h−1, respectively. Unfortunately, under these conditions, it is not possible to achieve the target TAN of the product (see Fig. 8 ), even though the pressure of hydrogen increased significantly to enhance the removal of naphthenic acid in the highly acidic crude oil feedstock. 3.4 Catalytic properties of catalyst in sulfide form In order to enhance the catalytic activity of the Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst at low temperature (<300℃), the catalyst was sulfidated, following the method described in the Experimental section. The sulfidation treatment was performed at 250℃, using 2.5 wt% DMDS in a kerosene solution before the catalytic measurement, and thus the treated catalyst was thoroughly washed by kerosene to avoid the effect of DMDS residue in the catalytic properties. The sulfur content of the Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in sulfide form was measured using an Antek 5000 system, showing the catalyst contains 2.6 wt% of sulfur species. In several previous literatures, it has been reported that sulfided Co-Mo catalyst shows high catalytic activity in various hydro-treating reactions such as hydrodeoxygenation [40]. Sulfur vacancies (coordinately unsaturated sites) that are located at the edges of MoS2 in sulfided Co-Mo nanoparticles are strongly active sites [41]. These sites exhibit Lewis acid character and can adsorb atoms with unpaired electron, thus acting an important role in scission of carbon-heteroatom (e.g., CO) bond. As shown in Fig. 8, the sulfide form catalyst can achieve the target TAN of the product oil (to 0.49 mgKOH/g) even at 250℃, where PH2, H2/Oil ratio, and LHSVfeed were 5.0 MPa, 25 Nm3/m3, and 5 h−1, respectively, while the oxide-form counterpart reduced the TAN of the feed to 1.32 mgKOH/g (much higher than target TAN). As mentioned above, the decrease of the reaction temperature to 250℃ is a notable merit in the refinery process to effectively lower the operation cost. The Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in sulfide form was also tested with varying various reaction parameters to find the optimized conditions. We set the standard conditions to T = 250℃, PH2 = 4.0 MPa, H2/oil ratio = 50 Nm3/m3, and LHSVfeed = 3.0 h−1, and we tested the sulfide-form catalyst with variation of each reaction parameter at once. As shown in Fig. 9 a, we confirmed that PH2 can be reduced from 5.0 MPa to 4.0 MPa while still satisfying the target TAN of the product. Below a PH2 of 3.0 MPa, the catalyst could reduce the TAN of the feed to 0.57 mgKOH/g. In the case of the H2/oil ratio, 40 Nm3/m3 was the minimum value to achieve the target TAN of the product (Fig. 9b). Fig. 9c shows that the highest LHSVfeed was 3.0 h-1 to operate the catalytic reaction of the TAN reduction while meeting the requirement. In the case of the Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in sulfide form, the optimized conditions are likely T = 250℃, PH2 = 4.0 MPa, H2/oil ratio = 40 Nm3/m3, and LHSVfeed = 3.0 h-1 (Fig. 10 ). We also performed a long-term catalytic stability test for the Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in sulfide form under the optimized reaction conditions for the sulfide catalyst except for increasing the H2/oil ratio from 40 to 50 Nm3/m3. The reason for setting the H2/oil ratio to 50 Nm3/m3 is that the TAN of the product at the initial period was already very close to 0.5 mgKOH/g, and thus a H2/oil ratio of 50 Nm3/m3 appears to be more suitable to operate the reaction safely for a long time. Under this condition, the sulfide-form Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst can maintain the TAN of the product crude oil below 0.5 mgKOH/g for 72 h of time on stream (Fig. 10). Similar to the oxide-form, it is likely that the catalytic activity of the sulfide-form catalyst will be maintained well for further reaction time, because a steep increase of TAN of the final product was not shown until 72 h of reaction. 3.5 Mechanism study on the removal of naphthenic acid From the present systematic studies on the catalytic reaction for TAN reduction of the highly acidic crude oil using the Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, we could confirm that the present catalyst is highly effective to reduce the TAN of the highly acidic crude oil (highly similar to naturally-existing crude) even at quite low temperature (250℃). As mentioned above, the reduction of TAN in the feedstock is due to the chemical removal of carboxylic acid groups of naphthenic acid in the highly crude oil feedstock. We can propose three possible reaction pathways for the chemical removal of carboxylic acid groups, which are shown in Figure S1. The carboxylic acid groups can be removed via decarboxylation, decarbonylation, and hydrodeoxygenation route. In order to verify our proposal for the mechanism, we confirmed the presence of the carboxylic acid groups in the feed and the product compound using FT-IR spectroscopy and we analyzed the gas species derived from the product compound using a GC analyzer. For this mechanism study, the Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in oxide form was used as a catalyst, and the reaction was performed under conditions of T = 350℃, PH2 = 0.5 MPa, H2/oil = 5 ∼ 25 Nm3/m3, and LHSVfeed = 2.5 h−1. As shown in Figure S2, the vibration peak for the carboxylic acid groups was shown at 1708 cm−1 wavenumber in the FT-IR spectra of the feedstock, but this peak almost completely disappeared in the FT-IR spectra of the product compound. This result indicates that the carboxylic acid group of the highly acidic crude oil was chemically removed. In addition, significant amounts of carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide, which were side products of decarboxylation and decarbonylation of naphthenic acid, respectively (see Figure S2), were detected in the GC measurement for the gas species of the product. A quantitative analysis of H2O species in the final product compound is difficult, because small amounts of H2O were also included in the feedstock crude oil. Nevertheless, we believe that these analysis results sufficiently support our proposed mechanism of naphthenic acid removal in the present catalytic reaction. 4 Conclusion In this work, we proposed an eco-friendly and economically-viable method for TAN reduction of highly acidic crude oil. This method uses the Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst to remove chemically carboxylic acid groups of naphthenic acids composed of highly acidic crude oil via catalytic hydrotreating pathways including decarboxylation, decarbonylation, and hydrodeoxygenation. To confirm the possibility of this reaction for TAN reduction, we synthesized Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in both oxide-form (as is) and sulfide-form (additional sulfidation treatment), and we used almost real highly acidic crude oil (not a simple model feed compound) that was prepared by mixing heavy crude oil (Castilla Crude) and naphthenic acid (TAN of this feedstock: 2.192 mgKOH/g). It is meaningful to use real crude oil-based feedstock to assess the applicability of the reaction in the real field of the refinery industry. The reaction was operated in a continuous fixed-bed up-flow reactor. We performed a systematic study on the catalytic reaction by varying various reaction parameters, in order to find the optimized conditions to achieve our target TAN in the product, 0.5 mgKOH/g, which is an acceptable level to meet the requirements of the conventional refinery industry. As a result, we demonstrated that the present oxide-form Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst can reduce the TAN of the feedstock to lower than 0.5 mgKOH/g for 82 h of time on stream, under the optimized conditions (T = 350 °C, PH2 = 0.5 MPa, H2/oil = 25 Nm3/m3, and LHSVfeed = 10 h−1). More interestingly, this catalyst can achieve the target TAN of the product at much milder condition (especially, lower temperature: 250℃) for 72 h, under optimized conditions for the sulfide-form catalyst (PH2 = 4.0 MPa, H2/oil = 50 Nm3/m3, LHSVfeed = 3 h−1). From the view point of applicability in the real field of the refinery industry, this method of catalytic TAN reduction of highly acidic crude oil has several notable advantages as follows: 1) the Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst is a relatively cheap and easily synthesized catalyst that is commonly used in the refinery process as a hydrotreating catalyst, 2) the reaction is operated in a continuous fixed-bed up-flow reactor, which is good for long-term operation with high productivity, 3) it was eco-friendly heterogeneous reaction that uses no toxic reagent and produces no toxic waste, 4) it is possible to enhance the catalytic activity of the catalyst at mild temperature via simple sulfidation treatment on the catalyst, 5) consequently, the reaction can be operated at 250℃, which can be reached by on-process heat or waste heat without installation of an additional heater, 6) the LHSV of the feed is sufficient to show high productivity, and 7) the present catalyst shows high long-term stability (checked for 72∼82 h in this work, but it will be possible to use the catalyst for much longer period). In addition, in comparison with other methods for TAN reduction such as physical mixing with non-acidic conventional crude oil, titration using NaOH, catalytic esterification, adsorption, and so on, this catalytic method appears to be more suitable for application in the refinery industry, owing to complete and irreversible removal of the acidic groups, the absence of need for toxic reagents, and no generation of waste that should be treated before emission. coredata.dc:description: We demonstrated catalytic removal of naphthenic acids in highly acidic crude oil over catalyst prepared by impregnating CoO-MoO3 on mesoporous γ-Al2O3, and its sulfidate-form treated via post-synthetic sulfidation treatment to increase activity at lower temperature. We used almost real highly acidic crude prepared mixing heavy Castilla crude oil and naphthenic acids; total-acid-number (TAN) of this feedstock was 2.192 mgKOH/g. Our target TAN of product was 0.5 mgKOH/g (requirement of conventional refinery industry). For optimizing reaction conditions, temperature, hydrogen-pressure, hydrogen-to-oil (H2/oil) ratio and liquid-hourly-space-velocity (LHSV) of feed were screened. The oxide-form catalyst reduced TAN to lower than 0.5 mgKOH/g for 82 h, under optimized condition (T = 350 °C, PH2 = 0.5 MPa, H2/oil = 25 Nm3/m3, and LHSVfeed = 10 h−1). After sulfidation, this catalyst achieved target TAN at lower temperature (250℃) for 72 h (PH2 = 4.0 MPa, H2/oil = 50 Nm3/m3, and LHSVfeed = 3 h−1). Mechanism study shows that the removal of naphthenic acids occurred mainly through decarboxylation, decarbonylation and hydrodeoxygenation.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic removal of naphthenic acids over Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst to reduce total acid number (TAN) of highly acidic crude oil
